variant.question: A SAFE LIFE aircraft structural component is:

options.text: Designed for finite number of hours or cycles.
Not affected by fatigue.
Designed to never require replacement.
Designed for an in-finite number of hours or cycles.

variant.question: The anti-icing method for the wings of large jet transport aeroplanes most commonly used in flight is

options.text: thermal (use of hot air).
chemical (glycol-based liquid).
electrical (electrical resistance).
mechanical (pneumatic boots).

variant.question: Turbine engine intake anti-icing uses:

options.text: hot air from the compressor
hot air from the turbine inlet
hot air from the turbine exhaust
hot air from the combustion chamber

variant.question: On which principle does the Rosemount Ice Detector operate on?

options.text: Vibration.
Pressure difference.
Translucence.
Voltage difference.

variant.question: The most common method for anti-icing the wings of large jet transport aeroplanes in flight is..

options.text: a hot air thermal system.
electrical resistive heater panels.
a glycol-based fluid system.
mechanical pneumatic boots.

variant.question: With transport category aeroplanes, de-icing of the vertical tail is...

options.text: installed in some types.
mandatory.
not possible with rubber boots.
accomplished using hydraulic fluid.

variant.question: A primary ice detection system can be defined as a system that..

options.text: can be relied upon as the sole means of detecting ice accretion or icing conditions.
only provides an advisory annunciation of the presence of ice accretion or icing conditions.
cannot be used to activate the ice protection systems.
only detects ice accretion on the primary flight control surfaces.

variant.question: The differential pressure ice detector is activated by

options.text: a decrease in dynamic pressure.
an increase in dynamic pressure.
a decrease in static pressure.
an increase in static pressure.

variant.question: Pneumatic mechanical devices that provide ice protection...

options.text: are used as de-icing devices.
can only be used as anti-icing devices.
are usually used on aeroplanes equipped with turbo-fan engines.
require large quantities of bleed air.

variant.question: What is correct regarding the “vibrating rod” ice detection system during icing?

options.text: It alerts the crew to icing with a light in the cockpit.
It accrues ice that is visible from cockpit instruments.
It accrues ice that may be seen from the cockpit windows.
It automatically activates anti-icing on accumulation of ice.

variant.question: The use of a hot air wing anti-icing system:

options.text: does not affect aerodynamic performance of the wing and causes a reduction in maximum thrust.
does not affect aerodynamic performance of the wing and causes no reduction in maximum thrust.
reduces aerodynamic performance of the wing and causes no reduction in maximum thrust.
reduces aerodynamic performance of the wing and causes a reduction in maximum thrust.

variant.question: A Hot Rod Ice Detection System indicates aircraft ice accretion by..

options.text: the ice build-up on the probe, which can be viewed from the cockpit.
the automatic activation of the aircraft de-icing system.
the activation of an ice-warning light in the cockpit.
the ice build-up on the probe, which is visible via a cockpit instrument.

variant.question: Pneumatic mechanical ice protection systems are mainly used for:

options.text: wings.
pitot tubes.
windscreens.
propellers.

variant.question: The wing ice protection system currently used for most large turboprop transport aeroplanes is

options.text: a pneumatic system with inflatable boots.
a liquid de-icing system.
an electrical de-icing system.
a hot air system.

variant.question: A hot rod ice detector

options.text: accumulates ice and is visible from the cockpit.
activates an ice warning light in the cockpit.
accumulates ice and is visible on an instrument in the cockpit.
activates the aircraft de icing system.

variant.question: Which of the statements describes a Hot Rod Ice Detector System?

options.text: The system consists of a heated probe and a built-in floodlight.
The system consists of a small heated pipe with several holes.
The system consists of a vibrating detector which can be heated.
The system consists of a temperature probe and moisture detector controller which in turn incorporates two heated sensors.

variant.question: An in-flight anti-icing system

options.text: prevents ice formation on the engine air intakes.
removes ice formed on the leading edge flaps.
removes ice formed on the tail surfaces.
prevents ice formation on the trailing edge flaps.

variant.question: When there is a pressure difference between the two sides of a pressure-operated ice detector, the...

options.text: heater in the probe melts the ice in the smaller holes first.
heater in the probe melts the ice in the larger hole first.
probe starts to rotate until maximum deflection and then the “icing light” comes on.
probe starts to vibrate until the differential pressure reaches zero.

variant.question: What is true about an ice detector which incorporates a rotor?

options.text: Measurement is based on torque.
Measurement is based on vibrations.
Measurement is based on measurement of temperature and humidity.
Measurement is based on pressure differences.

variant.question: How does the primary manual ice detection system operate?

options.text: The flight crew activates ice protection systems based on ice detector signals.
All ice detection systems are only used to alert the cockpit crew and ice protection systems are always activated by the flight crew manually.

The flight crew activates ice protection systems based on the standard flight manual criteria of a total temperature reading and the sighting of moisture. The ice detector signals serve as a back-up indicator.
The ice detector automatically activates ice protection systems at the optimal moment.

variant.question: Electrically powered ice protection devices on aircraft are used as

options.text: anti-icing devices for pitot-tubes, static ports and windshields.
de-icing devices for pitot-tubes, static ports and windshields.
de-icing devices for wings, wheel bays and aerials.
anti-icing devices for wings, wheel bays and aerials.

variant.question: Which statement about the tail ice-protection system is correct?

options.text: Some aeroplane tails have ice-protection systems.
It uses heat from hydraulic fluid running through the leading-edge pipelines.
The tail is protected from ice accretion by ram air.
It is mandatory for aeroplanes to have a tail ice-protection system.

variant.question:
The elements typically protected against icing on large transport aircraft are:
1) engine air intake and pod.
2) front glass shield.
3) radome.
4) pitot tubes and waste water exhaust masts.
5) leading edges of the wings.
6) cabin windows.
7) trailing edges of the wings.
8) electronic equipment compartment.
The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:
Pneumatic boots are used to...

options.text: de-ice the wing leading edges.
prevent ice formation on the wing leading edges.
de-ice the engine air intakes.
prevent ice formation on the engine air intakes.

variant.question: The inflatable boot de-icing system removes ice by:

options.text: Deformation.
Heating.
Vibrations.
Blowing away the ice.

variant.question: The heat for the anti-icing system of a turbofan engine intake is provided by:

options.text: bleed air from the HP compressor.
a dedicated generator on the gearbox of that engine.
the electrical system of the aircraft.
bleed air from the LP compressor.
2 and 3.
1 and 3.
2 and 4.
1 and 4.

variant.question: A Rosemount Ice Detector provides an indication of ice accretion by measuring the

options.text: resonant vibration frequency.
differential voltage.
differential temperature.
differential air pressure.

variant.question: Airborne fluid de-ice systems, where installed, are mainly used on..

options.text: wing leading edges.
engine intakes.
pitot probes.
engine pylons.

variant.question: The engine air intakes of large transport aircraft are usually protected against ice by...

options.text: hot bleed air.
pressurised fluid.
inflatable boots.
hot engine oil.

variant.question: In jet aeroplanes the thermal anti-icing system is primarily supplied by:

options.text: bleed air from the engines.
ram air, heated via a heat exchanger.
turbo compressors.
the APU.

variant.question: The wing anti-ice system has to protect

options.text: the leading edge or the slats, either partially or completely.
the whole upper wing surface and the flaps.
the whole leading edge and the whole under wing surface.
the whole leading edge except the slats because they cannot be de-iced when extended.

variant.question: The wing ice protection system currently used on most large jet transport aeroplanes is..

options.text: a hot bleed air system.
an electrical heater mat system.
an exhaust gas bleed system.
a weeping wing liquid system.

variant.question: Generally, for large aeroplanes, electrical heating for ice protection is used on

options.text: pitot tubes.
fin leading edges.
slat leading edges.
elevator leading edges.

variant.question: An ice detection probe can use differential pressure to provide an indication of ice accretion. Such a probe detects ice accretion due to

options.text: a decrease in dynamic air pressure in the detector.
an increase in static air pressure in the detector.
an increase in dynamic air pressure in the detector.
a decrease in static air pressure in the detector.

variant.question: On most transport aircraft, flight deck windows are protected against icing by:

options.text: electrical heating.
anti-icing fluid.
vinyl coating.
rain repellent systems.

variant.question: On most transport aircraft, flight deck windows are protected against icing by:

options.text: electric heating.
rain repellent system.
vinyl coating.
anti-icing fluid.

variant.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding a differential pressure ice accretion detector?

options.text: Small holes are heated first.
It always includes a temperature sensor and a moisture detector.
Large holes are heated first.
The torque of a rotating, serrated shaft is measured.

variant.question: The sequential pneumatic impulses used in certain leading edge de-icing devices can be triggered from the flight deck...

options.text: after icing has become visible and will inflate each pneumatic boot for a few seconds.
after icing has become visible and will repeat more than ten times per second.
before ice becomes visible to prevent ice formation and will repeat more than ten times per second.
before ice becomes visible to prevent ice formation and will inflate each pneumatic boot for a few seconds.

variant.question: When a turbo prop pneumatic de-icing system is switched on whilst at cruise

options.text: propeller RPM remains unchanged, turbine temperature rises and torque reduces.
propeller RPM remains unchanged, turbine temperature reduces and torque reduces.
propeller RPM remains unchanged, turbine temperature remains unchanged and torque remains unchanged.
propeller RPM reduces, turbine temperature reduces and torque increases.

variant.question: Which of the following components of a common turboprop aircraft (e.g. Dash 8) are protected by an anti-icing system?

options.text: Engine inlets, pitot tubes and static ports.
Wings, pitot tubes, static ports and waste water exhaust.
APU inlet, pitot tubes, static ports and wings.
Wings, pitot tubes and static ports.

variant.question: Which of the statements describes a Rosemount Ice Detector System?

options.text: The system consists of a vibrating detector which can be heated.
The system consists of heated probe and a built-in floodlight.
The system consists of a small heated pipe with several holes.
The system consists of a temperature probe and moisture detector controller which in turn incorporates two heated sensors.

variant.question: How is ice removed when using de-ice boots?

options.text: Deformation
Vibration
Blowing the ice away
Heat

variant.question: Concerning electrically powered ice protection devices, the only true statement is

options.text: on modern aeroplanes, electrically powered thermal devices are typically used to prevent icing on small surfaces (pitot-static, windshield, etc.).
on modern aeroplanes, electrically powered thermal devices are typically used as de-icing devices for pitot-tubes, static-ports, windshield etc.
on modern aeroplanes, electrical power supply being available in excess, this system is often used for large surfaces de-icing.
on modern aeroplanes, electrically powered thermal devices are very efficient, therefore they only need little energy.

variant.question: Foreign Object Damage is most likely to occur during

options.text: engine operation at or near the ground.
low-speed flight in turbulent air.
high-speed flight in icing conditions.
maintenance on the ramp or in the hangar.

variant.question: Ice protection for gas turbine engine intakes is typically required

options.text: when flying in cloud through super-cooled water droplets.
when flying in clouds in temperatures of +15°C.
at all times when the engine is running.
when on the ground in temperatures greater than +10°C.

variant.question: The ice protection system for the propellers of most turbo-prop aeroplanes operates

options.text: electrically.
with hot air.
pneumatically.
with anti-icing fluid.

variant.question: In jet aircraft equipped with a thermal anti-ice system, this is primarily supplied by..

options.text: bleed air from the engines.
mechanical anti-icing boots.
electrically heating the surfaces to be protected.
ram air, heated via a heat exchanger.
